title: Eurostar passengers see rail staff using an IRONING BOARD as work bench to fix signal

This is the bizarre moment a French rail engineer was spotted using an ironing board as a work bench while he hastily tried to fix broken signals delaying stunned Eurostar passengers.
Businessman Jamie Poyner, 40, was travelling from London St Pancras when an announcement was made saying the train would stop while work was done on the line.
It halted in the French countryside around 50 minutes from Brussels and Mr Poyner looked out of his window to see the trackside engineer using the ironing board as a work station.
Working flat out: Delayed Eurostar passengers were left stunned after witnessing a French rail engineer using an ironing board as a work bench while he hastily tried to fix broken signals
The man in high-vis uniform was standing behind some tape and surrounded by tools, resting some cabling and equipment on the board.
Mr Poyner, from Wakefield, Yorkshire, said: 'My carriage pulled up next to the work that was taking place.

'It all looked rather odd, but I suppose if it suited him and was safe he could use what he wanted.'
Eurostar said they could not comment on the odd equipment as they were not responsible for maintaining the tracks.
They said the engineer worked for SNCF, the French railway company.
It is not the first odd incident Eurostar passengers have experienced. Last year a businessman was banned from travelling on Eurostar trains for life after he was kicked off a train for complaining about the strength of his cup of tea.
Businessman Jamie Poyner, 40, was travelling on a train when it halted in the French countryside around 50 minutes from Brussels. He then looked out to see a trackside engineer using the ironing board (file photo)
Daniel Confino, then 56, a financial expert who was instrumental in saving the foundering Eurotunnel project in the Nineties, was furious to be told by email that he would never be allowed back on a Eurostar train unless he proved he could be ‘courteous and polite’.
The row began when he was returning with a colleague to St Pancras on September 6 2014 after a conference in Paris. In the buffet car he ordered two teas at £2.20 each – and asked for an extra bag so he could have a strong cup.
However, when he was charged £2.20 just for the third tea bag, he complained.
